source: Public YouTube video – “Complete Software Engineer Career Roadmap in 2024+”

level_1: The video explains what career roadmapping is and why planning your engineering career is important.
Beginners learn that choosing the right role helps avoid confusion and burnout.
level_2: It shows how to identify short-term (intern) vs long-term (staff engineer) roles.
Explains how to match your interests (like backend, AI) to job roles.
level_3: Discusses building a multi-year roadmap with milestones like projects, promotions, and skill upgrades.
Highlights role-matching: junior → mid → senior based on responsibilities and impact.
level_4: Shows how to align career roadmap with company goals and industry trends like AI.
Explains how senior/junior roles evolve based on roadmap and business objectives.

level_1: Choosing an internship aligned with your interest area.
Deciding between frontend or backend early in your learning.
level_2: Planning to build 2–3 small projects before applying for junior roles.
Mapping your roadmap: 6 months – learn DSA; 1 year – open-source contribution.
level_3: Creating a role-matching plan: moving from junior to mid-level via project leadership.
Adjusting roadmap based on mid-career interest shifts (e.g., shifting to AI).
level_4: Adjust roadmap every quarter based on industry trends like microservices or distributed systems.
Mentoring others to align their roadmaps with team goals.

level_1: College students use roadmaps to choose internships.
level_2: Early devs set growth milestones—DSA, coding proficiency.
level_3: Mid-level mids plan transition to senior or full-stack roles.
level_4: Tech leads align team career development with company strategy.

level_1: Ask: What role do I want next?
level_2: Plan: What skills or projects do I need?
level_3: Evaluate: Are my milestones realistic and measurable?
level_4: Align: Does my roadmap support business/industry direction?

level_1: Not choosing a clear path—leading to scattered learning.
level_3: Creating a roadmap without feedback—resulting in misalignment.
level_4: Sticking to a static roadmap—ignoring external changes.

level_2: Why match a role to your strengths?
level_3: How do milestones help reach your next role?
level_4: How do you align your roadmap with company goals?

level_1: List 3 career roles you’re interested in.
level_2: Create a 1-year roadmap with learning goals.
level_3: Draft a 3-year career growth plan and share with a mentor.
level_4: Help a peer build a roadmap aligned with their team objectives.

level_1: Don’t skip planning your first career step.
level_2: Avoid setting vague goals—use measurable milestones.
level_3: Don’t ignore mentor or peer feedback on your roadmap.
level_4: Avoid rigid roadmaps—review and revise quarterly.
